College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest Petroleum University Chengdu Sichuan 610500 PR China Carbon-based materials, particularly expanded graphite (EG), serve as excellent catalyst supports due to their high surface area, mechanical stability, and defect-rich structure. This study developed an amphiphilic Mo/Zn-EG-K catalyst by anchoring Zn/Mo oxides on EG and modifying it with KH550 silane, balancing lipophilic (methoxy) and hydrophilic (amino) properties to enhance oxidative desulfurization (ODS) efficiency. Characterization (TEM, Py-IR, etc.) confirmed the catalyst’s structure and amphiphilicity. Under optimized conditions (60 °C, O/S=10, 60 min), 99.12 % dibenzothiophene (DBT) conversion was achieved, reducing sulfur content below 10 ppm—outperforming most Mo-based catalysts. The reaction followed first-order kinetics, and the catalyst retained 95 % activity after five cycles. Mechanistic studies revealed that Zn enhances surface electrophilicity, promoting H₂O₂ activation to generate •O₂⁻ radicals, which form reactive Mo(O₂) species. These intermediates selectively oxidize DBT into polar sulfoxides/sulfones, subsequently extracted by acetonitrile. The catalyst demonstrated strong performance in real diesel and continuous-flow systems, highlighting its industrial potential for ultra-deep desulfurization. Keywords Amphiphilicity EG Bimetallic synergy Oxidative desulphurization Response surface optimization Clean fuels Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The presence of sulfur in fuels poses significant challenges, as it can poison precious metal catalysts, thereby increasing the production costs of refined oil products, and during combustion, it releases substantial amounts of sulfur oxides, which are harmful to the environment [1]. Consequently, the removal of sulfides from oil products has garnered global attention, prompting China to implement stringent production standards for clean fuels, limiting sulfur content to less than 10 ppm [2]. Although hydrodesulphurization (HDS) is a prevalent industrial process for oil desulphurization, it is characterized by demanding conditions, requiring high temperatures and pressures, as well as large quantities of costly hydrogen [3]. Furthermore, HDS exhibits limited efficacy in reacting with thiophene sulfides, such as benzothiophene, dibenzothiophene, and their derivatives [4]. This limitation underscores the urgent need for the development of alternative techniques to supplement HDS. Notably, oxidative desulfurization (ODS) technology presents a promising solution, as it operates under mild conditions, is environmentally friendly, and effectively removes recalcitrant thiophene sulfides [5]. Thus, ODS is anticipated to complement HDS in achieving minimal sulfur content in fuels, facilitating the production of cleaner fuel products. Oxidative desulphurization (ODS) technology effectively converts aromatic sulfides in oil into sulphones by employing catalysts and oxidants. These sulphones, due to their higher polarity, can be easily separated from the oil phase through extraction and adsorption, thereby achieving deep desulphurization [6]. The ODS process is typically discontinuous and consists of two main steps [7]. Initially, suitable catalysts and oxidants facilitate the conversion of sulfides in the fuel into highly polar sulfoxide or sulphone. Subsequently, these substances are efficiently extracted using extractants or adsorbents, while the catalyst is recovered for subsequent desulphurization cycles. A significant advantage of the ODS process is its cost efficiency; it is estimated to cost two-thirds less than the hydrodesulphurization (HDS) process, as it does not require expensive hydrogen. This makes ODS particularly suitable for small and medium-sized refineries that lack hydrogen generation units [8]. With ongoing research into ODS systems, the continuous development of new catalysts, and deeper exploration of the ODS mechanism, this technology is poised to become a leading method for producing clean energy in the future. Currently, oxidative desulfurization (ODS) technology encounters challenges related to the separation and reuse of homogeneous catalysts [9], which has shifted research focus toward heterogeneous catalysts to address these issues. In recent years, there has been rapid advancement in the development of ODS catalysts, including polymetallic oxides [10], metal-organic frameworks [11], carbon materials [12], and metal oxides [13]. Among these, transition metal oxides (TMOs) are particularly favored due to their abundance, ease of large-scale synthesis, cost-effectiveness, and stability in organic solvents, making them prevalent choices for catalysts in ODS technology [14]. Mehdi A. Shadmehri et al. [15]. explored the catalytic performance of a cobalt-doped catalyst, CoO/g-C3N4, prepared via the impregnation method for the ODS process. The study optimized the catalytic performance of CoO/g-C3N4 using Taguchi's method by varying parameters such as cobalt content, reaction time, reaction temperature, oxidant dosage, and catalyst dosage. The experimental results indicated that under optimal conditions—45 % cobalt loading, 80 min, 65 °C, 0.05 mL of oxidant, and 0.06 g of catalyst—the removal efficiency of target sulfides by CoO/g-C3N4 reached 86.7 %. Notably, the cobalt content was identified as the most significant parameter influencing the catalyst's application in the ODS process. In this catalytic oxidation system, the C-S bond typically interacts with a transition metal to form a highly active sulfide or sulfide complex, which subsequently reacts with the oxidant to produce peroxometallic substances. This reaction enhances electron transfer, thereby promoting the ODS reaction and the formation of corresponding sulfones [16]. Transition metals such as Mo, Co, Ce, V, Ti, and W are commonly utilized in catalytic processes [17]. Among these, molybdenum (Mo) exhibits distinct catalytic advantages due to its excellent oxidative properties, thermal stability, and high oxidation state, making it an efficient active substance in the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) process [18]. However, MoOx tends to agglomerate during ODS, necessitating its immobilization on carriers to mitigate this issue. Various carriers, including porous metal oxides [19], metal-organic frameworks [20], zeolites [21], and carbon materials [22], are employed for this purpose. Notably, MoOx/CuCo2O4, developed by Zijia Liu et al. [23], involves loading MoOx nanoclusters onto spinel-type porous metal oxides, serving as an effective catalyst for the AODS reaction. This configuration allows the spinel-type porous metal oxides to modulate the electronic structure of MoOx nanoclusters, with Mo(V) species acting as the active center in the desulfurization reaction. Under optimal conditions, using MoOx/CuCo2O4 as the catalyst and air as the oxidant, dibenzothiophene is converted to dibenzothiophene sulfone at 90 °C and atmospheric pressure, achieving a turnover frequency (TOF) of 16.2 h−1. Remarkably, the catalyst demonstrates no significant performance decay or structural deformation across six consecutive reuse experiments. Additionally, the incorporation of other active components within the carrier cavities or on their surfaces can enhance the dispersion of active sites, thereby synergistically promoting the conversion of the target substrate [24]. Elemental Zn, for instance, can serve as an active site, effectively inhibiting the agglomeration of active substances [25]. Ahmed GS et al. [26]. synthesized ZnO/zeolite nanoparticle catalysts via a simple wet impregnation method for oxidative desulfurization applications, achieving a 90.6 % conversion of mercaptans in light naphtha within 50 min using 8 % ZnO/zeolite catalysts. To optimize the reaction conditions for achieving 99 % desulphurization of mercaptans with an initial concentration of 335.33 ppm, experimental modeling identified 55 and 164 min as the most effective durations. The incorporation of metal oxides into catalysts imparts unique physicochemical properties, enhancing their effectiveness in converting organosulfur compounds. These materials can improve the dispersion of active components when employed with suitable support carriers [27]. However, the catalytic properties of metal oxides can vary significantly depending on the carrier used, emphasizing the importance of carrier selection. Expanded graphite (EG) emerges as a promising carrier due to its porous carbon structure, stable worm-like configuration, and large interlayer pores, which facilitate the loading and dispersion of active substances while ensuring excellent stability [28]. Lan et al. [29] prepared EG and proposed its novel application as an activated persulfate (PDS) catalyst. EG samples, prepared at varying swelling temperatures, were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), revealing a notable synergistic effect of the EG/PDS system in degrading acid red 97 (AR97). Unlike other carbon material catalysts, the Sp2 carbon structure in EG may serve as the primary active site in catalytic reactions. Among the samples, those treated at 600 °C demonstrated superior catalytic activity for PDS activation. Traditionally, weak interactions between carriers and active components lead to leaching and poor regeneration and stability of the active components within the carrier [30]. To enhance the interaction between expanded graphite carriers and active components, modifications are necessary. KH550, or 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane, serves as an efficient silane coupling agent due to its unique molecular structure, which includes an amino group and three methoxysilane groups. In oxidative desulfurization (ODS) systems, the amino groups contribute to hydrophilicity, facilitating improved contact between the catalyst and oxidant and mitigating the challenges of limited mass transfer in multiphase systems. Conversely, the methoxysilyl groups exhibit lipophilicity, enhancing the activity of metal oxide-loaded catalysts in ODS processes and aiding in the dispersion of catalysts within the oil phase, thereby improving the accessibility of reaction sites in non-homogeneous ODS reactions [31]. The dual nature of KH550's structure is instrumental in material surface treatment, enabling better interaction with diverse substances and enhancing ODS efficiency. Zhang et al. [32] synthesized an ultrathin amphiphilic C/Si shell Janus material from graphene oxide and SiO2, where the outer SiO2 layer provided hydrophilicity and the inner C layer offered hydrophobicity. By impregnating this amino-modified C/Si Janus material with keggin-type HPW, they developed an emulsion interfacial catalyst for ODS of fuel oil, achieving excellent emulsification (100 %) and desulfurization (99.62 %) rates. Despite these advances in ODS performance through surface modification, the catalysts lack the precision to selectively target specific sulfides during the ODS process. Consequently, the development of loaded porous carriers that offer both selectivity and optimal ODS performance remains a significant challenge. In this study, we rationally designed a bifunctional catalyst by utilizing strong bimetallic oxide interactions to co-immobilize both Zn and Mo active sites on EG. This approach effectively modulated the electronic structure of catalytic centers while increasing Lewis acid site density. Subsequent surface modification with the coupling agent KH550 endowed the material with balanced lipophilic and hydrophilic properties, resulting in an amphiphilic Mo/Zn-EG-K catalyst with enhanced interfacial activity. The oxidative desulfurization (ODS) conditions were systematically optimized using response surface methodology (RSM) with process parameters modeled through multivariate quadratic regression analysis. This methodology established a robust continuous functional model that precisely correlates response values with critical process parameters. Three-dimensional response surface analysis provided clear visualization of the optimal operating regime [33]. Significantly, this work represents the first demonstration of amphiphilic bimetallic EG-supported catalysts for fuel desulfurization, opening new avenues for enhancing the catalytic performance and practical utility of inorganic carbon materials in industrial applications. 2 Experiments 2.1 Materials n-octane (C8H18, Chengdu Cologne Chemical Co., Ltd.), thiophene (T, Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.), benzothiophene (BT, Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.), dibenzothiophene (DBT, Shanghai McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.), ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH₄)₆Mo (NH₄)₆Mo, Chengdu Cologne Chemicals Co., Ltd.), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, Chengdu Cologne Chemicals Co., Ltd.), expanded graphite (EG, Chengdu Cologne Chemicals Co., Ltd.), anhydrous ethanol (Chengdu Cologne Chemicals Co., Ltd.), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2,30 %, Chengdu Cologne Chemicals Co., Ltd.), Ltd.), acetonitrile (Chengdu Cologne Chemical Co., Ltd.), p-benzoquinone (BQ, Chengdu Cologne Chemical Co., Ltd.), tert-butanol (TBA, Shanghai Adamus Reagent Co., Ltd.), isopropylbenzene peroxide (CHP, Chengdu Cologne Chemical Co., Ltd.), and tert-butylhydrogen peroxide (TBHP, Shanghai Adamus Reagent Co., Ltd.), and all of them are analytically pure and can be used directly without further purification. All the chemicals in the experiment were analytically pure and could be used directly without further purification. The solutions were prepared with deionized water and corresponding solid reagents. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts EG-K: To initiate the reaction, 0.6 g of EG was introduced into a solution comprising 100 mL of anhydrous ethanol and 20 mL of deionized water, ensuring homogeneity through sonication and stirring. Subsequently, KH550 was incorporated into the mixture, and the reaction was allowed to proceed at ambient temperature for a duration of 12 h. Following this, the solution was transferred to a 100-mL high-pressure reactor and subjected to further processing in an electrically heated blast oven at 180 °C for an additional 12 h [34]. Upon completion of the reaction, the solution was extracted and subjected to centrifugation at 8000 rpm. The resultant solid product underwent three washes with anhydrous ethanol to eliminate any residual impurities. Finally, the product was dried under vacuum conditions at 100 °C for 8 h. Notably, the reaction was conducted in the presence of a minimal amount of water. Zn-EG: Initially, 0.2995 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water and stirred thoroughly for 10 min to ensure complete dissolution. Following this, 50 mL of anhydrous ethanol was added to the solution to initiate the reaction. Subsequently, 0.5 g of ethylene glycol (EG) was incorporated into the mixture and subjected to sonication for 30 min to achieve homogeneous mixing. The prepared solution was then transferred to a 100-mL reactor and placed in an electric blast oven, maintained at 180 °C for 12 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the solid product was isolated by centrifugation at 8000 rpm and washed three times with anhydrous ethanol to eliminate impurities. Finally, the product was dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 8 h [35]. Mo-EG: To prepare the solution, 0.2 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water through thorough stirring for 10 min. Subsequently, a certain amount of CTAB was added, and the mixture was subjected to ultrasonic stirring for 15 min. Following this, 50 mL of anhydrous ethanol was introduced, and the solution was continuously stirred while adding 0.5 g of EG, followed by another 10 min of ultrasonic stirring to ensure homogeneity. The resulting uniform solution was then transferred into a 100 mL reactor and heated in an electric blast oven at 180 ℃ for 12 h. Upon completion of the heating process, the solution underwent centrifugation at 8000 rpm and was washed three times with anhydrous ethanol. The solid material obtained was dried in an oven at 100 ℃ for 8 h and subsequently calcined at 350 ℃ in a muffle furnace for 2 h [36]. Under these reaction conditions, MoO3 was similarly prepared. Mo-EG-K and Zn-EG-K: The preparation method is the same as that of Mo-EG and Zn-EG, respectively, only replacing EG with EG-K. Mo/Zn-EG: Initially, 0.2 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water by stirring the mixture for 10 min. Following this, 0.059 g of CTAB was incorporated, and the solution was subjected to continuous stirring and sonication for an additional 15 min to ensure thorough mixing. While maintaining stirring, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was added to achieve a molar ratio of Mo to Zn of 1. Subsequently, 50 mL of anhydrous ethanol was introduced, resulting in a milky white appearance of the solution. The addition of 0.5 g of EG was followed by further stirring and ultrasonication for 15 min, during which the solution gradually turned black. The mixture was then transferred to a 100-mL reaction kettle and heated in an electric blast oven at 180 °C for 12 h. Post-reaction, the solution was centrifuged at 8000 rpm, and the resulting product was washed three times with anhydrous ethanol to eliminate impurities. The purified products were then dried in a vacuum oven at 100 °C for 8 h. Finally, the dried samples were ground into a fine powder, placed in a crucible, and calcined in a muffle furnace at 350 °C for 2 h. Mo/Zn-EG-K: The preparation method mirrored that of Mo/Zn-EG, with the addition of a specified amount of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O to achieve n(Mo)/n(Zn) ratios of 0.5, 1, and 2, respectively. During this process, EG was substituted with EG-K. The catalysts produced were subsequently designated as Mo/Zn-EG-K-0.5, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1, and Mo/Zn-EG-K-2. ( Fig. 1) 2.3 Characterization The infrared spectra were analyzed using a WQF-520 infrared spectrometer with a scanning range of 400 cm⁻¹ to 4400 cm⁻¹, manufactured by Beijing Ruili Instrument Co. For X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, the spectra were obtained using an X-ray diffractometer, model X′Pert PRO MPD, which employed Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54187 Å) as the X-ray source. The scanning rate was set at 5°/min, covering a range from 10° to 80°. Elemental analysis of the catalysts was conducted using an inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer, model Agilent 5110, to determine the relative content of catalyst elements. The elemental distribution on the catalyst surface was examined using a Zeiss Gemini 300 scanning electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 3 kV, accompanied by a Smartedx X-ray spectrometer. Catalyst morphology was analyzed by HR-TEM (JEOL F200, 200 kV) with elemental mapping via EDS (Oxford X-MaxN 80 T), confirming uniform metal oxide dispersion and characteristic lattice spacings. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were assessed using a Mike ASAP2460 nitrogen physical adsorption and desorption instrument from McMurray Tick, USA. Prior to testing, the catalysts underwent degassing under vacuum at 300 °C for 8 h. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were acquired using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer, which featured monochromatic Al Kα radiation (E = 1486.6 eV). Binding energies were corrected with reference to the C 1s peak of the catalyst at 284.8 eV. Surface acidity was determined by Py-IR using 10 mg self-supported wafers. After vacuum pretreatment (100°C, 1 ×10⁻³ Pa, 1 h) and pyridine adsorption at RT, spectra were acquired between 1700 cm⁻¹ following 30 min desorption at 150 °C, 200 °C, and 350 °C. The static contact angle and hydrophilic/hydrophobic properties of the catalyst surfaces were measured using a contact angle meter, model Data physics DCAT21. Substances were analyzed before and after the ODS reaction using a gas chromatography mass spectrometer model Agilent 7890A-5975C and a GCTS-3000 UV fluorescence sulfur analyzer. 2.4 Catalytic tests To assess the desulfurization performance of the catalyst, dibenzothiophene (DBT) was chosen as the target reactant in the catalytic oxidative desulfurization reaction. A specific quantity of DBT was introduced into an n-octane solution, followed by ultrasonication and stirring to ensure complete dissolution, resulting in a model oil with an initial sulfur concentration of 500 mg/L. In this context, the amount of sulfide (T/BT/DBT) added was determined using Eq. (1): (1) C 0 = m s m s + m octane × 32.06 M s × 10 6 Where: C0 - Initial Sulphur concentration of target sulphide, (mg/L); mS - mass of target sulphide, (g); moctane - mass of n-octane, (g); MS - Relative molecular mass of the target sulphide. In a three-necked flask, 20 mL of model oil and 20 mL of acetonitrile were combined, followed by the addition of a specified amount of catalyst and 30 % H2O2. The reaction was conducted at a temperature of 60 °C. After a predetermined time, a sample of the upper clear liquid was taken to measure the concentration of sulfur dioxide using gas chromatography (GC-2014C). The desulfurization efficiency of the catalyst within the oxidative desulfurization system was subsequently calculated, as outlined in Eq. (2): (2) η = [ ( C 0 − C ) / C 0 ] × 100 % Where: η - desulphurization rate (%);C0 - initial Sulphur concentration of target sulphide, (mg/L);C - concentration of target sulphide at the end of the reaction, (mg/L). Upon completion of the ODS experiment, the cooled mixed solution was transferred into a centrifuge tube. The catalyst was then subjected to multiple washes with acetonitrile to ensure thorough cleaning. Subsequently, the catalyst was effectively separated from the solution through centrifugation. After separation, the catalyst was dried in an electric blower oven set at 80 °C for a duration of 8 h [37]. The dried catalysts were then carefully stored in sample bottles and placed in desiccators for preservation. This preparation allows the catalyst to be reused in subsequent catalytic oxidative desulfurization experiments, enabling further investigation into its reusable performance. 2.5 Response surface experimental design Following initial factor screening through factorial design, response surface methodology (RSM) was employed for model refinement. A Box-Behnken Design (BBD) was implemented to investigate the interaction effects among reaction time, reaction temperature, and oxygen-to-sulfur (O/S) ratio—three critical parameters governing the oxidative desulfurization process. This approach enabled rigorous optimization of the Mo/Zn-EG-K-catalyzed continuous reaction system, with RSM validation confirming the optimal operational conditions. The experimental data were analyzed using the same software at a 95 % confidence level. Table S1 presents the factors and levels utilized in the study. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of the amphiphilic Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 The structure and morphology of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 were thoroughly characterized using various techniques, including FT-IR, XRD, SEM, N2 adsorption-desorption isothermal curves, and XPS. The FT-IR spectroscopy, as depicted in Fig. 2a, was employed to analyze the changes in functional groups across different materials. The spectra revealed that all six materials—EG, Zn-EG, Mo-EG, Zn-EG-K, Mo-EG-K, and Mo/Zn-EG-K-1—exhibited water stretching vibration peaks at 3615 cm⁻¹ and 1636 cm⁻¹, alongside CC stretching vibration peaks, indicating the successful introduction of EG [38]. Notably, the peaks at 605 cm2 and 900 cm2 were present in Mo-EG, Mo-EG-K, and Mo/Zn-EG-K-1. The 605 cm⁻¹ peaks are attributed to the Mo-O-Mo vibration of Mo6+, while the 990 cm⁻¹ peaks generally correspond to the stretching vibrations of MoO, confirming the formation of MoO3 through the calcination of molybdate [39]. The absence of characteristic Zn-O peaks in Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 is likely due to the low dosage of zinc nitrate and its uniform distribution. In-depth investigation of the crystal structures of the five materials was conducted using XRD characterization. The diffraction patterns, depicted in Fig. 2b, reveal strong peaks at 2θ = 26.603° and weak peaks at 54.793°, corresponding to the (002) and (004) crystal planes of EG, respectively. These findings align with previous literature, confirming the successful incorporation of EG into the materials [40]. Moreover, the crystalline structures of Zn-EG and Zn-EG-K demonstrate the presence of both EG and ZnO, although the ZnO peaks are of low intensity, suggesting that only a small amount of ZnO was formed during material preparation (PDF#99-0111). Analysis of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 reveals diffraction peaks at 2θ = 12.780°, 23.339°, 25.699°, 27.339°, 33.759°, and 46.319°, which correspond to the (020), (110), (040), (021), (040), (021), (111), and (061) crystal planes, respectively (PDF#35-0609) [41]. This indicates the successful integration of MoO3 as an active substance into Mo/Zn-EG-K-1. Additionally, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 exhibits diffraction peaks at 2θ = 47.535° and 56.591°, which are associated with the (102) and (110) crystal planes of ZnO [42]. The subdued intensity of the peaks can be attributed to the poor crystallinity of ZnO, as corroborated by the FT-IR characterization results. Furthermore, the absence of additional peaks in Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 indicates that no impurities interfered during the preparation process, confirming the successful synthesis of the material. Additionally, ICP-OES analysis revealed that the actual elemental content of Mo and Zn in Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 is 18.18 % and 3.53 %, respectively. The morphological structures of EG, Zn-EG, Mo-EG, Mo/Zn-EG and Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 were investigated by SEM characterization. As shown in Fig. S2, the Mo/Zn-EG retained the loose, worm-like structure characteristic of EG (Fig. S1a) and exhibited a multilayered lamellar morphology [43]. In contrast, the lamellar structure of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1, modified by KH550 surface treatment, became notably looser while preserving the worm-like configuration of EG. Mapping scanning images of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 revealed a substantial loading of substances on the EG surface, with a more uniform distribution of elements such as C, Mo, Zn, N, and O. These elements were identified as MoO3 and ZnO, based on FT-IR and XRD characterization results. The synergistic interaction between these active substances is hypothesized to enhance the opportunities for Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 to interact with sulfides, thereby improving its oxidative desulfurization (ODS) performance. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was employed to characterize the surface morphology of both modified catalysts, Mo/Zn-EG-K and Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 ( Fig. 3). The images revealed well-dispersed nanorod-shaped crystals exhibiting distinct lattice fringes. Specifically, Mo/Zn-EG-K displayed interplanar spacings of 0.28 nm and 0.23 nm, corresponding to the (022) plane of MoO3 and the (110) plane of ZnO, respectively. In contrast, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 showed slightly reduced interplanar distances (0.18 nm for MoO3 and 0.17 nm for ZnO), indicating further refinement of the metal oxide coordination environment through additional surface modification. This structural optimization resulted in enhanced dispersion of the active components, as evidenced by elemental mapping demonstrating homogeneous distribution of Mo, Zn, O, N, and C throughout the catalyst matrix. Table 1 illustrates that the modification of Zn-EG to form Mo/Zn-EG results in a reduction of specific surface area, total pore volume, and average pore diameter. This decrease can be attributed to the loading of MoO3 and ZnO active compounds on the surface of the expanded graphite (EG), with some infiltration into the pore structure, thereby occupying space within the pore channels and altering the physical parameters of Mo/Zn-EG. However, the N2 adsorption-desorption physical parameters of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 are higher than those of Mo/Zn-EG. This improvement is due to the introduction of KH550 surface modification, which promotes a synergistic interaction between Mo and Zn elements, enhancing the dispersion of MoO3 and ZnO on the EG. According to the IUPAC classification, the N2 adsorption-desorption isothermal curves of the three materials—Zn-EG, Mo/Zn-EG, and Mo/Zn-EG-K-1—depicted in Fig. 4a are identified as type IV adsorption isotherms. These curves exhibit a gradual increase in the amount of adsorbed gas with increasing partial pressure (P/P0), and all feature H3-type hysteresis loops [44]. The pore size distribution curves, shown in Fig. 4b and detailed in Table 1, reveal that the average pore sizes of Zn-EG, Mo/Zn-EG, and Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 are 19.18 nm, 18.95 nm, and 19.47 nm, respectively, classifying them as mesoporous materials. The mesopores primarily result from the stacking pores between the EG lamellae, which address the diffusion limitations of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 during reactions by facilitating the movement of sulfide and enhancing the exposure of active sites [45]. Additionally, the molecular diameter of DBT (6.07 × 9.81 Å) is significantly smaller than the pore diameter of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1, ensuring that the pore space is ample for DBT molecules to diffuse into areas containing ODS active sites. This diffusion capability supports rapid mass transfer, promoting effective contact between DBT and the active centers, thereby increasing the accessibility of the active sites. Ultimately, this enhances the performance of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 in the ODS process. The chemical states of the elements in Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 before and after the reaction were analyzed using XPS characterization, as illustrated in Fig. 5. The XPS total spectra (Fig. 5a) reveal the presence of characteristic peaks for elements C, Mo, Zn, N, and O, confirming their stable existence in Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 both pre- and post-reaction and indicating successful doping of Mo and Zn. The C 1s fine spectra (Fig. 5b) display three peaks corresponding to C-C, C-O, and CO bonds, with no significant changes before and after the reaction, suggesting the catalyst's stability. In Fig. 5c, the fine mapping of Mo 3d reveals four peaks at 235.83 eV, 233.94 eV, 232.69 eV, and 231.41 eV. The peaks at 235.83 eV and 232.69 eV are attributed to Mo6+ 3d3/2 and Mo6+ 3d5/2, indicating that Mo predominantly exists as MoO3, the active substance in the catalyst. The peaks at 233.94 eV and 231.41 eV correspond to Mo5+ 3d3/2 and Mo5+ 3d5/2 [46], suggesting that Mo5+ formation, likely due to Mo-N coordination and oxygen vacancy generation, enhances the catalyst's activity in the ODS reaction. The Zn 2p fine mapping (Fig. 5d) shows peaks at 1045.23 eV and 1022.12 eV, corresponding to Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2, confirming the presence of Zn2+ in the form of ZnO [47], consistent with XRD characterization. Compared with the post-reaction Mo/Zn-EG-K-1, the Zn 2p peak of the pre-reaction catalyst shifted toward lower binding energy, while the N 1s peak shifted toward higher binding energy. These observations suggest an increase in electron cloud density around Zn and electron transfer from the EG surface to Zn 2p orbitals. This electronic redistribution demonstrates that ZnO acts as a structural promoter, enhancing the conductivity of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 and increasing the electrophilicity of the active sites [48]. The O 1s fine mapping (Fig. 5e) reveals peaks at 532.62 eV, 531.12 eV, and 530.41 eV, identified as surface oxygen (OS), oxygen vacancies (OV), and lattice oxygen (OL), respectively. The increased density of oxygen vacancies post-reaction, as indicated by the OV/OL ratio, promotes H2O2 activation, thereby enhancing Mo/Zn-EG-K-1's activity [49] According to Fig. 5f, it was found that N 1s in Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 showed a peak at 398.64 eV, which was attributed to pyrrolyl nitrogen, suggesting that the abundant M-NX was partially embedded in the expanded graphite carbon layer, which could enhance the catalytic activity of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 [50] The nature of acid sites on the catalyst surfaces was determined by pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR) using pyridine as a probe molecule at different treatment temperatures. According to standard characterization protocols, the adsorption temperatures of 150° C, 200 °C, and 350 °C correspond to weak, medium-strong, and strong acid sites, respectively [51]. As shown in Fig. 6, both Lewis (L) and Brønsted (B) acid sites were identified on EG, Zn-EG, and Mo/Zn-EG catalysts. The characteristic vibrational bands at 1450, 1586, and 1611 cm⁻¹ were attributed to pyridine coordinatively bonded to Lewis acid sites [52], while the weaker absorption bands at 1490, 1542, and 1634 cm⁻¹ originated from pyridinium ions (C-C stretching vibrations) associated with Brønsted acid sites [53]. Comparative analysis revealed that Mo/Zn-EG exhibited a significant increase in Lewis acid sites compared to EG and Zn-EG, particularly at 150 °C, where the highest concentration of weak acid sites was observed (Fig. 6d). In contrast, the Brønsted acid sites showed consistently weak band intensities across all catalysts with no notable variations, indicating their negligible contribution to catalytic activity. These results demonstrate that Lewis acid sites dominate the surface acidity of Mo/Zn-EG, and the incorporation of Mo and Zn species effectively enhances the population of Lewis acid sites. As shown in Fig. S3a, the KH550-modified Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 catalyst exhibited a low oil-phase contact angle of 6.2°, demonstrating its lipophilic character. This exceptional oleophilicity enables complete dispersion throughout the oil phase, allowing immediate contact with sulfur-containing compounds and consequently facilitating efficient catalytic oxidative desulfurization. Complementary measurements in acetonitrile (Fig. S3b) revealed a static contact angle of 15.8°, confirming the simultaneous presence of hydrophilic properties. These dual wettability characteristics establish Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 as an effective amphiphilic catalytic system where the hydrophilic components promote oxidant (H₂O₂) storage and activation while the oleophilic surface maintains optimal dispersion in the oil phase [54]. This distinctive amphiphilic architecture significantly enhances interfacial contact between the oxidant and sulfur substrates, thereby substantially improving the overall oxidative desulfurization efficiency. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation The factors influencing the synthesis of the catalysts and the removal of DBT on the catalysts in different systems were investigated. The KH550 modification (≤15 wt%) tailored surface functionalities of exfoliated graphite (EG), achieving 85.3 % DBT conversion (Fig. S4a). Excess modifier (>15 %) presumably caused pore blockage through silane crosslinking. Subsequent Zn doping (6 wt%) optimized the electronic structure, inducing charge redistribution to enhance electrophilicity (Fig. S4b). As the catalytic center, Mo species were further modulated via Mo/Zn molar ratios for maximal ODS efficiency. As illustrated in Fig. S5a, within the same oxidative desulfurization (ODS) system, the catalysts Mo/Zn-EG-K-0.5, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1, and Mo/Zn-EG-K-2 demonstrated remarkable ODS performance, achieving DBT removal rates of 97.75 %, 99.67 %, and 98.58 % in model oils at 80 min, respectively. Notably, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 exhibited the highest desulfurization rate, meeting the criteria for deep desulfurization with a rate of 99.12 % at 60 min. Through six sets of controlled experiments, we systematically investigated the catalytic oxidative desulfurization performance of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 in different reaction systems. As shown in Fig. S6, when using only the Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 catalyst, the adsorption rate of DBT was merely 7.85 %, indicating limited inherent adsorption capacity. The DBT removal efficiency remained below 50 % when employing only the solvent acetonitrile for extraction (without catalyst) or only the oxidant H₂O₂ (without catalyst participation). Further studies revealed that the catalyst's surface adsorption capacity for DBT reached 53.63 % and 57.79 % under conditions without H₂O₂ or acetonitrile, respectively. These results clearly demonstrate that neither physical adsorption nor chemical oxidation alone can achieve satisfactory desulfurization performance in the catalytic oxidative desulfurization system. Excellent desulfurization efficiency can only be attained through the synergistic interaction among the catalyst, oxidant, and extractant, as subsequently confirmed by follow-up experimental results. The excellent desulfurization performance of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 can be attributed to the strong synergistic interaction between the bimetallic oxides on the EG surface. The introduction of Zn and Mo as active sites can effectively regulate the electronic structure of the catalytic center, increase the number of Lewis acid sites, accelerate the H₂O₂ oxidation, and thus greatly promote the ODS performance [48]. Additionally, the utilization of KH550 in the material preparation process improved the hydrophilicity and lipophilicity of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1. Enhanced lipophilicity aids in the adsorption of sulfides and the desorption of sulfone products on its hydrophilic surface, ensuring thorough mixing with H2O2 and promoting mass transfer during the ODS reaction [54]. Consequently, the catalyst's improved interaction with sulfides in the model oil leads to an increased desulfurization rate. Fig. S5b illustrates the impact of calcination temperature on the catalytic oxidative desulfurization performance of the catalyst. At a calcination temperature of 300 °C, the Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 catalyst achieved a desulfurization rate of 95.55 %. Upon increasing the temperature to 350 °C, the catalyst exhibited optimal performance, significantly enhancing the removal of DBT from the model oil to 99.12 % within 60 min. However, further increasing the calcination temperature to 600 °C resulted in a noticeable decline in oxidative desulfurization (ODS) performance, accompanied by a color change of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 from black to white. This decline is attributed to sintered agglomeration among particles, caused by the collapse of the pore structure at excessively high temperatures. Such structural changes lead to a reduced specific surface area, loss of active components, and a decrease in effective active sites, thereby diminishing the catalytic activity of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 [55]. Conversely, lower calcination temperatures are beneficial as they partially break the material's ligands, thereby exposing more active sites and enhancing desulfurization performance. In industrial applications, optimizing process conditions for effective desulphurization is crucial. A series of experiments initially obtained a range of optimal conditions for the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) process. The impact of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance was specifically examined. As the ODS is an endothermic reaction, higher temperatures generally enhance its efficiency(as in Fig. S7a). For instance, at a lower reaction temperature of 30 °C, the removal rate of dibenzothiophene (DBT) using the Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 catalyst was only 66.81 % after 60 min. However, when the temperature increased to 60 °C, the catalyst nearly achieved complete conversion of DBT within the same duration, with a desulphurization rate of 99.12 %, thereby achieving the target of deep desulphurization. Raising the temperature further to 70 °C resulted in a negligible improvement (99.33 %), suggesting that the thermal decomposition of H2O2 limited further enhancement of the ODS effect. Additionally, partial vaporization of the oil phase (C8H18) may have hindered effective contact between H2O2 and the active sites [56]. Therefore, considering both efficiency and economic feasibility, 60 °C was selected as the optimal temperature. The influence of different oxidants on the catalytic oxidative removal of DBT over Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 was investigated using cumene hydroperoxide (CHP), tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), and hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) at 60 °C. As shown in Fig. S7b, the DBT removal efficiency reached 60.89 % and 64.59 % after 60 min with CHP and TBHP, respectively. In contrast, when H₂O₂ was employed as the oxidant, the desulfurization efficiency significantly increased to 98.78 %, demonstrating its superior oxidative capability. The oxidative desulfurization (ODS) performance varied significantly depending on the oxidant used. TBHP typically requires elevated reaction temperatures for optimal performance; however, the selected temperature of 60°C in this system was insufficient to fully activate TBHP, leading to lower desulfurization efficiency. In contrast, CHP exhibited complete miscibility in the oil phase, which hindered its contact with the acetonitrile extractant, resulting in poor sulfur removal. H₂O₂, on the other hand, proved to be the most effective oxidant due to its low cost, ready availability, and environmental friendliness. Moreover, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 efficiently catalyzed the decomposition of H₂O₂, significantly enhancing the ODS reaction. Consequently, H₂O₂ outperformed both CHP and TBHP in desulfurization efficiency. Based on these findings, H₂O₂ was selected as the oxidant for all subsequent experiments. By employing acetonitrile as the extractant, the reaction products were effectively transferred into the acetonitrile phase, thereby preventing interfacial mixing issues [57]. The study examined the impact of varying oxygen-sulfur (O/S) ratios on the catalytic oxidative desulfurization (ODS) performance of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1, as illustrated in Fig. S7c. An increase in the desulfurization rate was observed as the O/S ratio rose from 4 to 10. This enhancement was attributed to the generation of more catalytically active radicals, facilitated by the increased addition of H2O2, which promoted the oxidation and removal of sulfur compounds, thereby improving ODS performance. However, when the O/S ratio further increased to 12, the excess H2O2 underwent thermal decomposition, producing water and O2 that were adsorbed around the active sites. This adsorption hindered mass transfer and was detrimental to the ODS reaction, ultimately inhibiting the reaction rate. As illustrated in Fig. S7d, increasing the dosage of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 enhances the contents of active substances, MoO3 and ZnO, which synergistically react with H2O2 to produce a substantial amount of reactive oxygen species. This reaction facilitates the oxidation of DBT to DBTO2, which, due to its increased polarity, is more readily removed, thereby improving the desulfurization efficiency of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1. When the dosage of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 reached 0.1 g, the oxidation of DBT was nearly complete, achieving the target sulfur content reduction to 10 ppm. However, further increasing the dosage to 0.12 g did not significantly enhance the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) activity. This lack of improvement is attributed to the excessive catalyst dosage, which may lead to the aggregation of active species, thereby inhibiting the ODS reaction to some extent and preventing a significant enhancement in the overall activity of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1. The data presented in Fig. S7a were linearly fitted using the proposed first-order kinetic equation, enabling the determination of the corresponding kinetic parameters, as shown in Fig. S7e. The reaction rate constant (k) exhibited an increasing trend with the rise in reaction temperature. Concurrently, the removal rate of DBT by Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 increased, consistent with the theory of molecular heat motion, which posits that higher temperatures lead to more vigorous collisions between active sites and other substances [58]. This increased collision frequency enhances the likelihood of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 contacting and reacting with sulfur dioxide, thereby improving desulfurization efficiency. Consequently, the process of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 acting on the ODS system can be classified as a first-order kinetic reaction. Utilizing the Arrhenius equation, the activation energy (Ea) was calculated to be 35.35 kJ/mol, as depicted in Fig. S7f. This relatively low activation energy barrier contributes positively to the ODS reaction[59]. Given the complex composition of organic sulfides in real fuel oils, it is imperative that the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) industry meets practical expectations. To this end, ODS experiments were conducted on thiophene compounds with varying initial concentrations (Fig. S8a). The findings indicate that Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 is particularly effective for treating model oils with low sulfur concentrations. As the initial sulfur concentration increases, the catalytic efficiency of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 diminishes at the same reaction time. This decline is likely due to the insufficiency of active sites on Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 to effectively remove sulfides from model oils with higher concentrations. Furthermore, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 exhibits a tendency to adsorb more oxidation products in high-concentration model oils, which consequently restricts its efficacy in the desulfurization reaction to a certain extent [60] In light of the complexity of sulfide species present in real oils, thiophene (T) and benzothiophene (BT), which are notably challenging to remove, were selected as target sulfides to investigate the catalytic oxidative desulfurization performance of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1. Fig. S8b illustrates that the reactivity of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 towards various sulfides follows the order: dibenzothiophene (DBT) > BT > T. This order correlates with the electron density of the sulfur atoms, measured as 5.758, 5.739, and 5.696, respectively, thereby demonstrating the influence of electron density on reactivity [61]. The removal rates of the different sulfides by the catalyst are determined by a combination of spatial site resistance and the electron cloud density of each sulfide. Analysis of the experimental results indicates that the electron cloud density of the sulfides predominantly influences the reactivity of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 with T, BT, and DBT in the oxidative desulfurization system. The reactivity of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 towards the three sulfides increases in tandem with the electron density of the sulfur atoms, and the oxidation reaction of the sulfides proceeds via an electrophilic addition mechanism [62]. To comprehensively assess the catalytic oxidation performance of the Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 catalyst, we summarized the catalytic oxidative desulfurization data from recently prepared catalysts for the ODS reaction, as shown in Table 2: Transition metal-loaded catalysts are widely explored in catalytic research due to their ability to achieve ultra-low sulfur levels. As summarized in Table 2, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 reduces the sulfur content in treated model oil to <10ppm, meeting the stringent National VI standard and demonstrating practical applicability [70]. Under optimized conditions (500 ppm initial sulfur, H₂O₂ oxidant, 60 °C, 60 min), Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 achieves 99.12 % DBT conversion. Notably, it outperforms most reported catalysts by requiring milder reaction conditions (lower temperature, shorter time) and a simpler preparation process while still attaining <10ppm residual sulfur, highlighting its superior oxidative desulfurization (ODS) efficiency. However, its performance is more suited to low-sulfur feedstocks (e.g., 500 ppm). At higher sulfur concentrations (1000 ppm), the catalyst’s active sites become occupied by adsorbed oxidation products like DBTO₂, inhibiting its ODS activity due to competitive adsorption and reduced accessibility of active sites. In industrial applications, catalysts are essential not only for their high catalytic activity but also for their reusability and stability. As shown in Fig. S9a, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 exhibits excellent reusability, maintaining stable performance over multiple cycles. After five consecutive regeneration cycles (via acetonitrile washing), the catalyst retained a desulfurization efficiency of 94.21 %, representing only a 5 % decrease compared to the fresh catalyst (99.12 %). Remarkably, even after eight cycles, the efficiency remained as high as 90 %, demonstrating its outstanding long-term stability. However, a slight reduction in performance compared to fresh catalysts was observed, which can be attributed to the partial loss of active material and pore clogging. This clogging is caused by the oxidation product DBTO2, which accumulates on the surface of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 during multiple reactions [71]. After use, Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 was recovered through centrifugation, washed with acetonitrile, and subjected to structural analysis via X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization (Fig. S9b). The XRD results confirmed that the crystal structure of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 remained unchanged before and after the reaction, although a decrease in crystallinity was noted. This reduction in crystallinity is likely due to the attachment of DBTO2 produced during several ODS reactions to Mo/Zn-EG-K-1. Building on its excellent catalytic performance, the Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 composite was evaluated for real diesel fuel desulfurization under identical ODS conditions. Initial sulfur content of 647 mg/L (measured by GCTS-3000 UV fluorescence sulfur analyzer) was reduced to 55.97 mg/L after 120 min at 60 °C, achieving a 91.35 % desulfurization rate (Fig. S10a). Remarkably, the catalyst maintained 76 % efficiency after five consecutive ODS cycles (Fig. S10b), demonstrating both good stability and practical applicability for continuous real diesel treatment. 3.3 Optimization of the desulphurization process by response surface methodology (RSM) Response surface analysis reveals significant interactions between key operating parameters in the Mo/Zn-EG-K catalytic oxidative desulfurization system. The optimized conditions identified through this analysis show excellent agreement with the experimental results obtained in Section 3.2. This consistency validates both the accuracy of the model in evaluating factor interactions and the feasibility of the optimal ODS conditions initially determined through single-factor experiments. Additional details of this validation are provided in the Supporting Information. 3.4 ODS mechanism In the catalytic oxidative desulfurization (ODS) reaction involving Mo/Zn-EG-K-1, the detection of reaction products is essential for elucidating the potential reaction mechanism. During the reaction, samples from both the oil phase in the upper layer and the acetonitrile phase in the lower layer were periodically collected and subjected to GC-MS analysis. The analysis results, depicted in Fig. 7a, reveal that the oil phase contains a prominent peak for dibenzothiophene (DBT, m/z = 184) alongside a solvent peak. Notably, the characteristic peak of DBT diminishes as the reaction progresses. Concurrently, Fig. 7b) illustrates a rapid increase in the intensity of the DBTO2 peak (m/z = 216) within the acetonitrile phase. These observations suggest that the primary steps of the ODS reaction involve the oxidation of DBT to DBTO2, facilitated by the combined action of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 and H2O2. The insolubility of DBTO2 in the oil phase allows for its effective removal, thereby contributing to the production of low-sulfur fuel oil. To investigate the reactive oxygen species generated during the ODS reaction of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1, free radical quenching experiments were conducted. In these experiments, p-benzoquinone (BQ) and tert-butanol (TBA) were employed to quench the superoxide radical (•O₂⁻) and hydroxyl radical (-OH), respectively, while AgNO3 and ethanolamine (EDTA) served to quench electrons (e-) and holes (h+), respectively (Fig. 7c) [69]. The results indicated that the addition of tertiary butyl alcohol (TBA) had a minimal impact on the ODS performance, whereas benzoquinone (BQ) exhibited a more pronounced inhibitory effect. This suggests that the superoxide radical (•O₂⁻) is the primary active radical in this ODS system. To identify the reactive oxygen species involved in the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) process, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy was performed using 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) as a spin-trapping agent under standard reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 7d, no EPR signals were observed in the blank control (absence of catalyst, oxidant, and extractant). However, after 5 min of catalytic reaction, a characteristic six-line signal corresponding to •O₂⁻ radicals was detected, confirming their generation during the ODS process [72]. The signal intensity increased progressively with reaction time, indicating sustained •O₂⁻ production. Complementary radical quenching experiments further confirmed that •O₂⁻ serves as the primary active species, selectively oxidizing dibenzothiophene (DBT) to its corresponding sulfone (DBTO₂), thereby significantly enhancing ODS efficiency. This observation aligns with previous reports demonstrating that molybdenum oxides (MoOX) rapidly react with H₂O₂ to form molybdenum-peroxo (Mo–OOH) intermediates, which are critical for ODS activity by facilitating •O₂⁻ generation [73]. Based on the analyses presented above, the mechanism of Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 in the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) reaction can be hypothesized, as illustrated in Fig. 8. Initially, under vigorous stirring, sulfides such as hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and dibenzothiophene (DBT) diffuse into the surface or pores of the amphiphilic Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 catalyst. This diffusion results in a rapid increase in the concentration of H2O2 and DBT around the catalyst, thereby accelerating the oxidation reaction between H2O2 and DBT. Meanwhile, the interaction of H₂O₂ with the active substances (Mo, Zn) in Mo/Zn-EG-K-1 was promoted to produce more Lewis acid sites under the addition of electrophilicity of Zn-blended catalysts, which resulted in the rapid decomposition to produce •O₂⁻ radicals. These radicals are subsequently oxidized to form the reactive metal peroxide Mo(O2). At this juncture, the sulfur atoms of DBT nucleophilically adsorb onto Mo(O2), resulting in the formation of DBTO2. Additionally, a small amount of Mo(O2) may undergo thermal decomposition to produce •O₂⁻ radicals, further oxidizing DBT. Ultimately, the oxidation products are removed from the oil phase through simple washing with acetonitrile. Upon completion of the ODS reaction, H2O2 is converted to water (H2O), and Mo(O2) is reduced to MoO [73]. This reduction allows for a new cycle of the ODS reaction, continuing until deep oxidative desulfurization is achieved. 4 Conclusion In this study, an efficient amphiphilic bimetallic synergistic catalyst, Mo/Zn-EG-K, was developed through hydrothermal and calcination methods. The incorporation of two primary active sites, Zn and Mo, maximized the strong interactions between the bimetallic oxides on the EG surface, thereby optimizing the electronic structure of the catalytic active center, enhancing the synergistic interaction between the bimetals, and increasing the Lewis acidic sites. The addition of the silane coupling agent KH550, which contains hydrophilic amino groups and lipophilic methoxysilane groups, facilitated improved interaction of the catalyst with DBT and H2O2 at the liquid/liquid interface. In the oxidative desulfurization (ODS) system, the hydrophilic nature of the catalyst allowed for better mixing and reaction with the oxidant, addressing the issue of limited mass transfer in multiphase systems. Concurrently, the lipophilic properties enhanced the dispersion of the catalyst in the oil phase, improving the accessibility of active sites in the heterogeneous ODS reaction, thereby increasing the efficiency of ODS. The ODS process was preliminarily optimized by one-way experiments, and the optimum combination of conditions for Mo/Zn-EG-K catalytic oxidative desulfurization was further investigated and verified by response surface modeling (RSM). Achieving a high DBT conversion of 99.12 % in 60 min at 60 °C, with the desulfurization rate decreasing by only 5 % after five cycles of reuse, indicating good reusability and stability. The catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic activity and stability in continuous ODS cycles using real diesel fuel, showing promising potential for practical applications. The dual properties of KH550 enhanced the mass transfer efficiency in the multiphase system, while the active components were highly dispersed on the stable EG carrier, resulting in a composite catalyst with high activity and excellent stability. In conclusion, this study provides a valuable reference for the design of new inorganic composite carbon materials with high activity and stability for future industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Carbon-based materials, particularly expanded graphite (EG), serve as excellent catalyst supports due to their high surface area, mechanical stability, and defect-rich structure. This study developed an amphiphilic Mo/Zn-EG-K catalyst by anchoring Zn/Mo oxides on EG and modifying it with KH550 silane, balancing lipophilic (methoxy) and hydrophilic (amino) properties to enhance oxidative desulfurization (ODS) efficiency. Characterization (TEM, Py-IR, etc.) confirmed the catalyst’s structure and amphiphilicity. Under optimized conditions (60 °C, O/S=10, 60 min), 99.12 % dibenzothiophene (DBT) conversion was achieved, reducing sulfur content below 10 ppm—outperforming most Mo-based catalysts. The reaction followed first-order kinetics, and the catalyst retained 95 % activity after five cycles. Mechanistic studies revealed that Zn enhances surface electrophilicity, promoting H₂O₂ activation to generate •O₂⁻ radicals, which form reactive Mo(O₂) species. These intermediates selectively oxidize DBT into polar sulfoxides/sulfones, subsequently extracted by acetonitrile. The catalyst demonstrated strong performance in real diesel and continuous-flow systems, highlighting its industrial potential for ultra-deep desulfurization.

coredata.dc:title: Efficient desulfurization of model diesel fuel using an amphiphilic bimetallic synergistic catalyst Mo/Zn-EG-K
